Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Maintain passenger safety and provide assistance during service.
Situation2: A report has come in about a suspicious, unattended bag in one of the train cars.
Story: I stared at my phone, my sister’s message lighting up the screen: “Don’t forget, we’re all counting on you to be there tonight. It won’t be the same without you.” My family had planned this holiday dinner for weeks, and I’d promised I wouldn’t miss it this time. But as the subway rumbled beneath the city, my radio crackled with urgency—security had just reported an unattended bag in car three. My heart pounded. As the operator, I was responsible for everyone’s safety. I was supposed to stay calm, follow protocol, and make sure no one panicked. But my mind kept drifting to my family, waiting for me, expecting me to show up and be present, not just in body but in spirit. I felt torn, the weight of both worlds pressing down on me, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait. I gripped the controls, caught between the duty to my passengers and the promise I’d made to my family, not knowing which role I could bear to let down.
